page.title: 03CAREBY
page.content: Mostly stone built, Careby has nine houses west of the railway, one being an isolated brick one up the Holywell road; another was converted from the old school. Apart from a farm \km away to the north (now a private house), the rest of the village (15 houses) lies east of the line, down a quiet lane leading to the church and river. The newest building developments in Careby are a garage beside the railway line, built to look like a private house, and a large single-storey house converted from a square of red brick farm buildings. Two cottages are empty and semi- derelict. A similar row across the river was recently renovated and made into one house. The road used to continue beyond them to Witham on the Hill, but was reputedly closed off to isolate Careby from the plague.
